name: Eye  Optic nerve
description: The optic nerve (CN II) is an extension of the central nervous system, surrounded by meninges. It consists of myelinated axons of retinal ganglion cells.

features: Bundles of myelinated nerve fibers (axons of retinal ganglion cells)
Surrounded by Dura, Arachnoid, and Pia mater (meninges)
Septa of connective tissue carrying blood vessels
Central Retinal Artery and Vein in the center
Glial cells (Astrocytes, Oligodendrocytes) support the axons
location: Extends from optic disc to optic chiasm
function: Transmits visual information from retina to brain
theory.examTips: It is NOT a true peripheral nerve (surrounded by meninges, not epi/peri/endoneurium). Myelinated by Oligodendrocytes (like CNS), not Schwann cells. This explains why Optic Neuritis is common in Multiple Sclerosis (CNS demyelination).

name: Eye  Retina Choroid and Sclera
description: The wall of the eye consists of three tunics: Fibrous (Sclera), Vascular (Choroid), and Neural (Retina). The retina has 10 distinct layers.

features: Sclera: Dense irregular connective tissue (Type I collagen)
Choroid: Highly vascular, pigmented (melanocytes), loose CT
Retina: 10 layers including Rods/Cones, Ganglion cells, Bipolar cells
Retinal Pigment Epithelium (RPE): Outermost retinal layer adjacent to choroid
Bruch's membrane separates choroid and retina
function: Choroid: Nutrients to outer retina, light absorption
theory.examTips: Know the 10 layers of retina in order (from outside in): RPE -> Photoreceptors -> External Limiting Membrane -> Outer Nuclear -> Outer Plexiform -> Inner Nuclear -> Inner Plexiform -> Ganglion Cell -> Nerve Fiber -> Internal Limiting Membrane. 'In the eye, light passes through all layers to reach the photoreceptors'.

name: Eye - Conjunctiva
description: The conjunctiva is a transparent mucous membrane covering the anterior eye (bulbar) and inner eyelids (palpebral). It contains goblet cells for lubrication.

features: Stratified columnar epithelium (unusual) with goblet cells
Becomes stratified squamous near corneal limbus
Lamina propria: Loose connective tissue with lymphocytes
Vascular
Melanocytes may be present
theory.examTips: Epithelium is key: Stratified Columnar with Goblet Cells. This is a rare epithelial type in the body (also found in large ducts). Inflammation = Conjunctivitis ('Pink Eye') due to dilation of its vessels (sclera is avascular).

name: Eye - Cornea
description: The cornea is the transparent anterior part of the eye. It is avascular and consists of 5 layers.

features: Epithelium: Non-keratinized stratified squamous (rich nerve supply)
Bowman's layer: Acellular basement membrane
Stroma (Substantia Propria): 90% of thickness, regular Type I collagen lamellae
Descemet's membrane: Thick distinct basement membrane
Endothelium: Simple squamous/cuboidal (pumps water out)
location: Anterior 1/6th of the outer fibrous coat
function: Refraction of light (2/3 of total refractive power)
theory.examTips: Cornea is AVASCULAR (gets O2 from air/aqueous humor). Transparency due to regular arrangement of collagen + dehydration. Epithelium regenerates (Bowman's does NOT). Endothelium does NOT regenerate.

name: Eye - Iris and Ciliary body
description: The Iris controls light entry (pupil). The Ciliary Body produces aqueous humor and controls lens accommodation.

features: Iris: Anterior stromal border (no epithelium), Stroma with melanocytes
Iris posterior epithelium: Two layers of HIGHLY pigmented cells
Sphincter pupillae (smooth muscle in stroma) & Dilator pupillae (myoepithelial)
Ciliary Body: Ciliary processes covered by double layer of epithelium
Ciliary muscle (smooth muscle for accommodation)
function: Ciliary Body: Aqueous humor production (non-pigmented cells), Accommodation (muscle)
theory.examTips: Ciliary epithelium outer layer is PIGMENTED (continuity with RPE), inner is NON-PIGMENTED (continuity with neural retina). Glaucoma = blockage of aqueous drainage at iridocorneal angle.

name: Eye - Whole globe
description: A cross-section of the whole globe allows visualization of the relationships between the anterior and posterior segments, lens, and fluid chambers.

features: Lens: Capsule, Subcapsular epithelium (anterior only), Lens fibers
Anterior Chamber & Posterior Chamber (filled with Aqueous Humor)
Vitreous Cavity (filled with Vitreous Humor)
Ora Serrata: Junction between independent retina and ciliary body
Fovea Centralis: Depression in macula (visual acuity)
theory.examTips: Note the Lens: Epithelium is ONLY on the ANTERIOR surface. New lens fibers are added throughout life (older fibers compressed in nucleus -> Presbyopia/Cataract). Fovea has NO blood vessels and mostly Cones.

name: Orbit - Lacrimal gland
description: The lacrimal gland is a tubuloacinar exocrine gland secreting the aqueous layer of the tear film. It resembles the parotid gland but lacks striated ducts.

features: Serous acini (tall columnar cells, apical secretory granules)
Myoepithelial cells at base of acini
Ducts lined by simple/stratified cuboidal epithelium
NO striated ducts (different from salivary glands)
Lymphocytes/Plasma cells in interstitium
theory.examTips: Looks remarkably like Parotid Gland (Serous). Differentiate by: ABSENCE of striated ducts in Lacrimal Gland. Also, Lacrimal Gland often has more widely spaced acini and more adipose tissue with age.
